news_summary: Advancements in quantum-inspired algorithms are enhancing our ability to detect and uncover hidden cosmic objects in space.

news_summary_es: Los avances en algoritmos de inspiración cuántica están mejorando nuestra capacidad para detectar y descubrir objetos cósmicos ocultos en el espacio.

articles.title: Quantum-inspired algorithm could help reveal hidden cosmic objects
articles.summary: Combining a quantum-inspired algorithm and quantum information processing technologies could enable researchers to measure masses of cosmic objects that bend light almost imperceptibly
articles.content:
A galaxy cluster produces gravitational lensing, bending light around it NASA, ESA, Michael Gladders (University of Chicago); Acknowledgement: Judy Schmidt

Quantum physics may be the secret ingredient for understanding cosmic objects that our telescopes cannot show us in detail, or at all.

To understand space, we collect and analyse light that travels from objects like stars into our telescopes, but that light doesn’t always travel in straight lines. Often, as it passes by a very massive object, such as a planet or a black hole, the light’s trajectory bends and creates distorted images as if an extra lens was added somewhere along the way.

But what about objects that are not cosmic heavyweights and have relatively small masses? Traditional imaging methods struggle with such “microlensing” events, but Zhenning Liu at the University of Maryland and his colleagues have now shown a protocol for analysing light that accounts for its quantumness could do much better.

They focused on leveraging the quantum properties of light to discern the mass of objects that cause microlensing. Liu says researchers can tell when a microlensing event happens, because the light becomes brighter. This allows them to know there is an object between us and the light’s source, but if that object is not huge, they cannot infer its mass from the properties of the light that telescopes already measure. Such objects could include small, isolated black holes and even some rogue planets.

But light is made from photons, which are quantum particles, so information about their journey towards Earth also gets encoded into their quantum properties. Notably, whenever a photon has the option of taking multiple different paths around an object, each of which requires a different travel time, that difference changes the photon’s quantum properties. Because quantum particles can sometimes behave like waves, these photons can effectively take both paths around an object simultaneously, like a water wave encountering a rock. The team’s protocol excels at extracting the time difference between both paths, which can then be translated into the object’s mass.

Liu says a planet or black hole creating microlensing would not necessarily be invisible in all other observations. But those methods may require collecting a lot more light, which is equivalent to having to build ever larger telescopes. The quantum approach would work with relatively few photons.

For instance, his team’s mathematical analysis showed the protocol would work well for stars in the galactic bulge, a part of the Milky Way where dark objects have previously been discovered through studies of gravitational lensing. Because the new protocol does not require a full-fledged quantum computer and could be implemented with more standard devices that capture and analyse one photon at a time combined with conventional computers, it also stands a chance of being tested in practice within a few years.

Daniel Oi at the University of Strathclyde in the UK says the quantum approach offers an exponential improvement in the ability to extract time delay information from light, an advantage that he likens to a holy grail of quantum technology. Oi says quantum technologies are a natural match for weak astronomical signals like small numbers of photons, because quantum theory is the origin of many of the limits on just how precisely something can be measured in physics.

Reference: arXiv, DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2510.07898
articles.reasoning: The article describes a novel quantum-inspired algorithm that could significantly improve the ability to measure masses of small cosmic objects through microlensing, overcoming limitations of traditional imaging. This breakthrough has broad implications for astronomy and space science by enabling detection and analysis of previously hidden or hard-to-measure objects like small black holes and rogue planets. The method is practical, does not require full quantum computers, and could be tested soon, indicating meaningful real-world impact and scientific advancement.
articles.personality_title: New quantum-inspired method helps weigh hidden cosmic objects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – When light from stars passes near massive space objects like black holes, it bends and creates distorted images, a phenomenon called gravitational lensing. Scientists use this to study big objects, but smaller ones like rogue planets or tiny black holes cause only subtle bending called microlensing, which is hard to measure with regular telescopes.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of Maryland developed a new method that uses quantum properties of light to better study microlensing. Light is made of photons, which can travel multiple paths at once due to quantum behavior. By analyzing tiny differences in photon travel times, the team’s method can estimate the mass of the small objects causing the light to bend.

**Impact** – This approach can detect and measure objects that are too small or faint for traditional methods, such as isolated black holes or rogue planets. Unlike other techniques that need huge telescopes or lots of light, this quantum-inspired method works with fewer photons and standard equipment. It could soon be tested in real observations, helping astronomers find hidden objects in our galaxy.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to try their method on stars in the Milky Way’s central region, where small dark objects have been spotted before. Since the method doesn’t need a full quantum computer, it might be put into use within a few years to improve how we study space.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new quantum-inspired technique could soon help scientists measure the masses of small, hidden cosmic objects by analyzing the quantum nature of light bending around them.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle méthode inspirée de la physique quantique pour peser les objets cosmiques cachés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Lorsque la lumière des étoiles passe près d’objets spatiaux massifs comme les trous noirs, elle se courbe et crée des images déformées, un phénomène appelé lentille gravitationnelle. Les scientifiques l’utilisent pour étudier les gros objets, mais les plus petits comme les planètes errantes ou les petits trous noirs provoquent une courbure subtile appelée microlentille, difficile à mesurer avec les télescopes classiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université du Maryland ont développé une nouvelle méthode utilisant les propriétés quantiques de la lumière pour mieux étudier la microlentille. La lumière est composée de photons, qui peuvent emprunter plusieurs chemins à la fois grâce à leur comportement quantique. En analysant de petites différences dans le temps de trajet des photons, la méthode peut estimer la masse des petits objets qui courbent la lumière.

**Impact** – Cette approche permet de détecter et mesurer des objets trop petits ou trop faibles pour les méthodes traditionnelles, comme des trous noirs isolés ou des planètes errantes. Contrairement à d’autres techniques nécessitant de très grands télescopes ou beaucoup de lumière, cette méthode inspirée de la physique quantique fonctionne avec moins de photons et du matériel standard. Elle pourrait bientôt être testée en observation réelle, aidant les astronomes à découvrir des objets cachés dans notre galaxie.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’appliquer leur méthode aux étoiles dans la région centrale de la Voie lactée, où des petits objets sombres ont déjà été repérés. Comme la méthode ne nécessite pas d’ordinateur quantique complet, elle pourrait être utilisée dans quelques années pour améliorer l’étude de l’espace.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une nouvelle technique inspirée de la physique quantique pourrait bientôt aider les scientifiques à mesurer la masse de petits objets cosmiques cachés en analysant la nature quantique de la lumière qui se courbe autour d’eux.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo método inspirado en la física cuántica ayuda a medir objetos cósmicos ocultos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cuando la luz de las estrellas pasa cerca de objetos espaciales muy masivos como agujeros negros, se dobla y crea imágenes distorsionadas, un fenómeno llamado lente gravitacional. Los científicos usan esto para estudiar objetos grandes, pero los más pequeños como planetas errantes o agujeros negros pequeños causan una ligera desviación llamada microlente, que es difícil de medir con telescopios normales.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Maryland desarrollaron un nuevo método que usa las propiedades cuánticas de la luz para estudiar mejor la microlente. La luz está hecha de fotones, que pueden tomar varios caminos al mismo tiempo debido a su comportamiento cuántico. Analizando pequeñas diferencias en los tiempos de viaje de los fotones, el método puede estimar la masa de los objetos pequeños que causan la desviación de la luz.

**Impacto** – Este método puede detectar y medir objetos que son demasiado pequeños o débiles para los métodos tradicionales, como agujeros negros aislados o planetas errantes. A diferencia de otras técnicas que requieren telescopios muy grandes o mucha luz, este enfoque inspirado en la física cuántica funciona con menos fotones y equipo estándar. Podría probarse pronto en observaciones reales, ayudando a los astrónomos a encontrar objetos ocultos en nuestra galaxia.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean aplicar su método a estrellas en la región central de la Vía Láctea, donde se han detectado objetos oscuros pequeños. Como el método no necesita una computadora cuántica completa, podría usarse en unos pocos años para mejorar el estudio del espacio.

**Frase clave** – Una nueva técnica inspirada en la física cuántica podría ayudar pronto a los científicos a medir la masa de pequeños objetos cósmicos ocultos analizando la naturaleza cuántica de la luz que se desvía a su alrededor.
